--- Your Response ---

Right, so the books aren't balancing as they should. My wages from ItalyMerchant down at the public dock have been clipped again, now to 2275 ducats, which stings. But what truly bites is ConsiglioDeiDieci nearly quadrupling the rent I pay for that very same dock space to a hefty 2100 ducats! While I've managed to increase the rent on my new fisherman's cottage to 1435 ducats, and thankfully young Lorenzo Contarini (a namesake, it seems) has moved in, that income barely covers the new dock rent, let alone my other expenses or ambitions. Speaking of which, it's a bit of an embarrassment that I'm still listed as homeless despite owning property; I must rectify that immediately, and find myself a proper meal too, as this hunger isn't helping my focus. My ducats stand at just over 107,000 after that cottage investment, so further large construction is off the table for now. My primary concern is stabilizing my finances: I need to either find a way to reduce this crushing dock rent, perhaps by appealing to my membership in the Arte dei Mercanti for alternative arrangements or leveraging my knowledge of trade flows to secure more profitable work. "Per Mare et Laborem" is my family's way, and the docks are my domain, but if ItalyMerchant can't offer better terms, or if ConsiglioDeiDieci remains unyielding, I'll need to be more 'calculating' and find new avenues to ensure my ducats grow, not shrink. Perhaps it's time to see if my "observant" nature can spot an overlooked opportunity in the bustling trade of our Serenissima.

While I pay my dues to the Consiglio for the land under my own cottage, this squeeze makes me question my loyalty to ItalyMerchant. My years on these docks, observing every crate and every deal, have given me an understanding of trade that few possess. Perhaps it's time to leverage this knowledge, "Per Mare et Laborem" as my family says, but maybe not entirely in ItalyMerchant's service. My focus remains on trade and property, but first, I must stabilize my own footing and ensure my expenses don't outpace my earnings, especially with the ever-present hand of the Consiglio influencing the costs of doing business in this city.
